title: Ukrainian soldiers in the Donbas rush to fortify their defensive lines ahead of the Russian army
summary: A few kilometers from the front, Ukrainian military engineers are racing against time to thwart the Russian advance into the Donetsk region, digging trenches and setting up rows of 'dragon's teeth' or 'Czech hedgehogs' to block the approaching enemy tanks.

title: US Vice President Harris calls for 'immediate ceasefire' in Gaza
summary: Kamala Harris' comments were the strongest to date by a US administration official on Israel. She is due to meet with Benny Gantz, a centrist member of Israel's war cabinet, in Washington on Monday.

title: The French far right's nebulous plan to unravel the EU
summary: Though Jordan Bardella, the Rassemblement National party's president, has denied aiming for a 'hidden Frexit,' he has promoted a sort of buffet-style EU, with states being free to pick and choose whether to participate – or not – in all forms of EU 'cooperation.'

title: Switzerland votes to boost pension payments but not to raise the retirement age
summary: In a double national referendum on retirement policy, 58.24% of Swiss voters backed a measure to add a 13th monthly payment to retirement pensions, while also voting at 74.72% against proposal to gradually raise the country's retirement age from 64 to 65.

title: Violence in Haiti: Hundreds of inmates flee after armed gangs storm main prison
summary: At least five people were dead Sunday.

title: Can a human brain be male or female?
summary: A study by researchers from Stanford University has confirmed that there are behaviorally relevant differences in human brain organization between men and women – a result that calls for caution in its interpretation.

title: The self immolation of Aaron Bushnell, an 'extreme protest' for Palestine in Washington
summary: On February 25, amid mounting protest against Joe Biden's support for Israel, an American serviceman shouted, 'Free Palestine,' before setting himself on fire in front of Israel's embassy in the US.

title: India's UPI mobile payment system: A soft power tool
summary: Since 2016, UPI has been revolutionizing purchasing in India and has generated €2 trillion by 2023.

title: 'The Economist' discontinues its Chinese-language edition
summary: The British business magazine is to close its Chinese app nine years after launching it, for economic and political reasons.

title: School uniforms, an obstacle to sports participation
summary: A British study has showed that wearing school uniforms, common in many countries, can restrict students' physical activity during the school day and beyond, particularly among girls.

title: Macron and his charcuterie board. Does anyone care?
summary: Having not received the warmest welcome at the Paris Agricultural Show, the French president found salvation at a Europe-tinged tasting session.

title: Pakistan elects Shehbaz Sharif as prime minister, amid protests and accusations of rigging
summary: Sharif, for his second term as PM, will have to renegotiate an IMF bailout of Pakistan, wracked by economic, security, and democratic crises. His election was marred by accusations of rigging and the imprisonment of his main opponent, Imran Khan.

title: Channel migrant deaths: 7-year-old girl killed in crossing attempt
summary: In the third fatal Channel crossing incident this year, a small boat containing 16 migrants headed to the United Kingdom from northern France capsized, killing the young girl and leading to other passengers, including her family, being sent to hospital.

title: 'Lucky, Brioche and Me': A staggering tale of war
summary: The Ukrainian writer Oleksandr Mykhed was living near Kyiv when the war broke out just two years ago. He fled and joined the army as a volunteer. His parents, both academics, stayed on in Bucha, a city symbolic of the conflict. Everything has since changed: houses, bodies, feelings, friendships.

title: '170 people executed' in Burkina Faso village attacks
summary: According to a regional public prosecutor, 3 villages in Burkina Faso were attacked a week prior, killing 170 and wounding others, among them women and young children. Another, separate, attack that week hit a mosque and church in the country's north.

title: Mexico: Claudia Sheinbaum launches her presidential campaign, intertwining themes of environmental stewardship, feminism, and the perpetuation of AMLO's transformative legacy
summary: The former Head of Government of Mexico City, Sheinbaum emerges as the formidable frontrunner for the forthcoming June 2 election. She held her first major rally in the capital on Friday, March 1.

title: Paris Olympics 2024: Testing on algorithmic video surveillance of the Games begins
summary: Authorized by a law for the Olympic Games, so-called 'augmented' video surveillance will be tested for the first time at two Depeche Mode concerts in Paris on Sunday, March 3, and Tuesday, March 5.

title: In the Alps, snow melts and air traffic soars
summary: On the bucolic shores of the Lac du Bourget, protests mount against Chambéry Airport, which is used every winter by an ever-increasing number of British tourists and private jets.

title: Ursula von der Leyen's reappointment at stake in European elections
summary: The president of the European Commission is focusing on her succession as head of the European executive, even if this means being very flexible on the priorities of her first term.

title: US: Nikki Haley wins her first primary in the District of Columbia
summary: Washington is one of the most heavily Democratic jurisdictions in the nation, with only about 23,000 registered Republicans in the city.

title: In the Arctic night, a new prey called jellyfish
summary: In the winter waters off Svalbard (Norway), several species of crustaceans feed on these essentially watery creatures, long considered inedible.

title: France's left-wing Jews, divided by their politics, still find unity through faith
summary: Several groups representing the progressive Jewish community have been rallying to make their voices heard since the Hamas massacres in Israel on October 7. But while they have much in common, they are divided into two opposing groups: the anti-Zionists and those more focused on fighting anti-Semitism.

title: Thousands of South Korean doctors rally against plan to increase admissions in medical schools
summary: As of Thursday night, 8,945 of the country's 13,000 medical interns and residents were confirmed to have left their worksites. Officials say South Korea's doctor-to-population ratio is one of the lowest among developed countries.

title: In Morocco, Rabat's mayor, criticized for her management, resigned
summary: Asmaa Rhlalou was forced to step down from her position after the Ministry of Interior insisted that she explain how she used the city's budget.

title: Saint-Eustache church: Where faith meets culture
summary: This majestic 800-year-old church – 'not only a place of worship, but also of culture' – in the central Les Halles district of Paris celebrates creation in all its forms.

title: SpaceX launches new crew to International Space Station
summary: Seven people are currently aboard the ISS. After an overlap of a few days, four members of the current ISS crew – an American, a Dane, and one person each from Japan and Russia – will return to Earth in their own capsule.

title: Rugby: France beats Great Britain to claim Los Angeles Sevens men's title
summary: New Zealand also easily overpowered Australia to win their second back-to-back women's title on Sunday.

title: How Trump is reshaping the Republican Party
summary: In the run-up to the November presidential election, the front-runner in the Republican primaries is methodically organizing the submission and purging of his party, starting with the chair of the Republican National Committee, who is being pushed out.

title: Turkey: The whistle blows in narco land
summary: Under the leadership of new Interior Minister Ali Yerlikaya, massive anti-drug operations are being conducted in this country, which has become a sanctuary for drug lords from all over the world.

title: Sex at the office: Why the boss can't flirt anymore
summary: While romantic relationships are accepted between colleagues of equal rank, they are frowned upon when one partner is a member of the company hierarchy, due to suspicions of coercion.

title: Are smartphones doomed to disappear?
summary: The golden age of smartphones may be coming to an end. In a saturated market, sales are plummeting, mainly due to a lack of major innovations over the past 15 years. In addition, a new generation of connected devices is overshadowing them.

title: French foreign minister: 'The humanitarian situation in Gaza is creating indefensible and unjustifiable situations for which the Israelis are accountable'
summary: Stéphane Séjourné, France's new head of diplomacy, believes that 'France must be on the right side of history' regarding the war in Ukraine, and is calling for a 'lasting' ceasefire in the Palestinian enclave.

title: Enshrining abortion in the French Constitution is a win for feminism and democracy
summary: The move supports women's freedom to control their own bodies and is also a positive sign for the democratic system, which has managed to overcome political divisions.

title: Why Israel attacks the UN agency for Palestinian refugees
summary: Israel accused 12 UNRWA members of participating in the October 7, 2023 attack. These allegations, which have yet to be substantiated, threaten to bring down an organization that plays a crucial humanitarian role in Gaza.

title: Russia's Luftwaffe eavesdropping scandal embarrasses Olaf Scholz
summary: The opposition is calling for the German chancellor to explain himself after Moscow broadcast a discussion between senior German air force officers on the possibility of supplying Ukraine with Taurus cruise missiles.

title: European Commission unveils ambitious defense industry strategy
summary: Brussels is proposing to co-finance joint arms acquisitions by member states and the modernization of factories in the sector, as well as new tools to strengthen companies in the face of their American competitors.

title: Five sports-related movies to watch with your teens
summary: "Moneyball" with Brad Pitt, "Air" by Ben Affleck, "Dodgeball" by the duo Ben Stiller and Vince Vaughn... Our selection of made-in-USA feature films to (re)discover with your stadium-loving, physical-feat-adoring children.

title: Olga Smirnova, former Bolshoi Ballet star: 'I won't return to a Russia without freedom'
summary: The former soloist at the prestigious Moscow ballet company, who left her country shortly after the start of the Russian invasion of Ukraine, lives exile in Amsterdam.

title: EU fines Apple €1.8 billion for antitrust violations in music streaming
summary: The European Commission ruled that Apple prevented music streaming services from informing users about subscription options outside of its App Store.

title: The first time Le Monde wrote SOB
summary: The insult, used against Vladimir Putin by Joe Biden, first appeared in the newspaper on April 14, 1951, after it was uttered by Republican Senator Joseph McCarthy.

title: France set to anchor abortion freedom in the Constitution
summary: Both the Assemblée Nationale and Sénat will meet in Versailles on Monday to take a final vote on the inclusion of abortion in the Constitution. The three-fifths majority needed to validate the reform looks almost guaranteed.

title: In Rafah, Gazans struggle to survive under the constant threat of Israeli attacks
summary: Stuck at the still-closed Egyptian border, more than a million Palestinians barely survive, traumatized, in an area of around 64 square kilometers.

title: Supreme Court restores Trump to ballot, rejecting states' bans over Capitol attack
summary: The court ruled unanimously, a day before Super Tuesday, that Colorado and other states cannot invoke a constitutional provision to remove him from the presidential ballot.

title: Pegasus probe in Poland reveals unprecedented use of spyware by previous government
summary: The new liberal majority has set up a parliamentary commission of inquiry to shed light on the use of the spying software by the previous populist government, particularly against opposition figures.

title: France enshrines 'freedom' to abortion in Constitution, in world first
summary: A joint session of Parliament voted to adopt a constitutional reform to protect the 'freedom of women to voluntarily terminate a pregnancy, which is guaranteed.' The move was designed as a response to the US Supreme Court overturning the federal right to abortion in 2022.

title: Jack Teixeira pleads guilty to leaking American military secrets
summary: The member of the Massachusetts Air National Guard agreed to a sentence of 17 years in prison, according to the plea agreement.

title: Iran's conservatives unsurprisingly dominate elections, amid record-low turnout
summary: The main coalition of reformist parties, the Reform Front, had said it would not take part in 'meaningless, non-competitive and ineffective elections.'
